questions.answerA: Ride in the portion of the lane that will bring you into other drivers' fields of vision at the earliest possible moment.
questions.answerB: Always be in the left lane to be the farthest from oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Slowly sneak up to the intersection.
questions.answerD: Weave slightly in your lane so your headlight has a better chance of being spotted.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection, move into the part of the lane that will bring you into an oncoming driver's field of vision at the earliest possible moment. For example, when approaching a blind corner to your right, you may be seen sooner if you are in the left portion of your lane and not in the center portion.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see.
questions.answerB: Avoid placing you in other drivers' blind spots.
questions.answerC: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerD: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not considered protective clothing?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerC: Long pants made of denim
questions.answerD: Athletic shoes
questions.explanation: In the event of a fall, a motorcyclist can receive protection from a leather jacket, long pants made of heavy denim, and full-fingered gloves. It is best for a motorcyclist to wear lace-up boots, high-top boots, or heavy shoes that support their ankles.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a position that will allow the other driver to see you in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a car, you should position yourself so you can be seen in the other driver's rearview mirror. Riding in the center portion of the lane will generally ensure that you will appear in the middle of their rearview mirror, where the driver is most likely to notice you.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: Both brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerD: Only one brake, front or rear, should be used.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. Always apply the brakes simultaneously.

questions.question: If only one alcoholic drink is consumed:
questions.answerA: Judgment and riding abilities can still be affected.
questions.answerB: There is usually no effect on the body.
questions.answerC: There is an effect on the body, but it only lasts for a short time.
questions.answerD: There is an effect on the body, but it can be eliminated by drinking coffee.
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can significantly affect the skills that are needed for safe riding. The only way to remove the alcohol content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it.

questions.question: When stopped behind another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close as possible to the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Maintain a space cushion between your motorcycle and the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not use your rearview mirrors to monitor traffic behind you.
questions.answerD: Look for opportunities to squeeze through the stopped traffic.
questions.explanation: You should stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even when you are both stopped. This will give you room to escape if the vehicle backs up unexpectedly or if another vehicle approaches too quickly from behind.

questions.question: Which formation is best for a group of riders entering a curve?
questions.answerA: Pyramid
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When a vehicle attempts to pass you from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Move to the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move to the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about which portion of the lane you are using.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being too close to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision.

questions.question: On a motorcycle, a horn:
questions.answerA: Is useless.
questions.answerB: Usually cannot be heard by others.
questions.answerC: Can be used to get someone’s attention quickly.
questions.answerD: Should not be used.
questions.explanation: Your horn can be a useful tool if you need to get someone's attention quickly. However, because a motorcycle's horn is not as loud as a car's, other drivers may not notice that you are sounding your horn. You should never rely only on your horn to deal with a hazard.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat and you must brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake of the tire that is not flat.
questions.answerB: Apply the brake of the tire that is flat.
questions.answerC: Apply both brakes.
questions.answerD: Not use either brake.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat and you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat (if you are certain of which tire that is).

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerA: One second
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not wear a jacket if it's warm out.
questions.answerB: Always wear a jacket, even if it’s warm out.
questions.answerC: Wear shorts in warm weather.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about long shoelaces.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket made of appropriate material when riding. This is true even in warm weather because wearing a jacket is important to help prevent dehydration. You should also always wear long pants, and tuck in the laces of your footwear to prevent them from catching on the motorcycle.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Comfort.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: Motorcyclists riding in a group should avoid pairing up because:
questions.answerA: A merging driver may not see both riders.
questions.answerB: Reflections from both helmets may make it difficult for the riders to see.
questions.answerC: Riding in pairs does not allow riders the necessary space to maneuver.
questions.answerD: It is too difficult for riders on the left side of a pairing to exit a highway.
questions.explanation: When traveling in a group, it is never recommended for motorcyclists to ride in pairs. Neither rider will have adequate room to maneuver to avoid hazards.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerC: Reduce your space cushion.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: In which of the following situations should you increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: Traffic is light.
questions.answerC: You are able to see the roadway through vehicles in front of you.
questions.answerD: There is pleasant and clear weather.
questions.explanation: While a two-second following distance is generally adequate, you should increase your following distance any time conditions would require a longer stopping distance, such as when the pavement is slippery due to poor weather conditions. Additionally, you should increase your following distance at night, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead, and when traffic is heavy.

questions.question: Under ideal conditions, you should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a minimum two-second following distance. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: The primary source of information about your motorcycle should come from:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle's former owner.
questions.answerC: A library book about motorcycles.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle enthusiast.
questions.explanation: The owner's manual should be your primary source of information about your specific type of motorcycle. Be sure to read the manual before operating your motorcycle for the first time.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerA: Always
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcyclists will seldom hear their tire go flat. Tire failure is more commonly indicated by a sudden change in handling.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: A driver making eye contact with you:
questions.answerA: Means that they see you.
questions.answerC: Does not mean that they will properly yield to you.
questions.answerD: Guarantees that they will properly yield to you.
questions.explanation: You should never count on eye contact to guarantee that a driver will yield to you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist but fail to consciously notice them.

questions.question: Gloves can:
questions.answerA: Make it difficult to control a motorcycle and should be avoided.
questions.answerC: Provide an improved grip on the handlebars.
questions.answerD: Offer no protection.
questions.explanation: Gloves can provide you with an improved grip on your motorcycle's handlebars. They can also protect your hands in the event of a crash.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerA: Remaining alert.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: A potential danger of braking too hard is:
questions.answerA: Losing traction on one or both wheels.
questions.answerB: Coming to a complete stop before you expect to.
questions.answerC: Popping a tire.
questions.answerD: Taking too long to stop.
questions.explanation: If you over-apply your brakes, you may lose traction on one or both wheels and crash.

questions.question: Head and neck injuries can be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Wearing a helmet.
questions.answerC: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerD: Wearing goggles.
questions.explanation: The risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by wearing a high-quality helmet. A helmet is a rider's best defense against injury in the case of an accident.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerD: Welcome other drivers into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: If you find yourself riding alongside another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up or slow down.
questions.answerC: Stay alongside the vehicle until the next exit and then exit.
questions.answerD: Let the other driver worry about it.
questions.explanation: Riding directly next to another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if another hazard arises. If you find yourself riding directly alongside another vehicle, either speed up or drop back.

questions.question: A properly-fitted motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Allows the rider to touch the ground with their feet while seated.
questions.answerB: Has a seat even with the rider's waist.
questions.answerC: Has a seat that is 10 inches above the rider's waist.
questions.answerD: Has a seat that is 10 inches below the rider's waist.
questions.explanation: If your motorcycle fits you properly, your feet should be able to reach the ground while you are seated. When riding your motorcycle, keep your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Intersections are usually:
questions.answerA: Safe since there is so much traffic there.
questions.answerC: Difficult to figure out.
questions.answerD: Safer than the open road.
questions.explanation: Intersections can be dangerous because they present the greatest degree of potential conflict between motorcyclists and other drivers.

questions.question: If you wait one hour to ride after having one alcoholic drink:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and driving.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected by the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Effects from the alcohol may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be fine as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, it is still possible for alcohol to accumulate in a person's system even if they consume only one drink per hour. This accumulation can still affect their ability to ride safely.

questions.question: What is the primary psychoactive component in marijuana?
questions.answerA: THC
questions.answerC: MRT
questions.answerD: AAP
questions.explanation: The main psychoactive substance in marijuana is called tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC.

questions.question: Who should set the pace in a group of riders?
questions.answerA: The leader
questions.answerB: The riders just behind the leader
questions.answerC: The rider in back
questions.answerD: The oldest rider
questions.explanation: The last rider in a group of motorcyclists should set the pace of travel. Having the last rider set the pace will ensure that no riders are left behind.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerA: Lean as you lean.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the seat as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: Passengers should lean as the operator leans. A passenger should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: When riding at night you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Use the vehicle in front of you to help see.
questions.answerD: Wear tinted glasses.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: When riding at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Be flexible about your lane position and adjust to changing conditions.
questions.answerB: Travel at a faster speed than usual to get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Always use your low beam headlight to see better.
questions.answerD: Decrease your following distance so you can be as close as possible to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: Always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night. Be especially careful to employ safe riding strategies when riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time could result in all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Fatigue.
questions.answerC: Severe chills.
questions.answerD: Hot flashes.
questions.explanation: Riding in cold weather for long periods of time can cause severe chill, fatigue, and even hypothermia. Be sure to wear proper clothing to protect you from the elements.

questions.question: Riders who do not wear helmets while riding are ________ to die in a crash than riders who do wear helmets.
questions.answerA: Half as likely
questions.answerC: Three times as likely
questions.answerD: Just as likely
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: If your front tire locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the brake engaged until you come to a full stop.
questions.answerB: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.answerC: Release the brake lever and use only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release the brake lever until the tire regains traction.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the brake lever until the tire regains traction and re-apply the brake.

questions.question: If you accidentally lock your rear wheel while braking on a good traction surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep it locked until you come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Release the rear brake and only use the front brake.
questions.answerC: Release the rear brake, then quickly re-apply it.
questions.answerD: Release the rear brake and down shift.
questions.explanation: If you accidentally lock the rear brake on a good traction surface, keep it locked until you have completely stopped. Even with a locked rear wheel, you should still be able to control your motorcycle if it is upright and traveling in a straight line.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerC: Reduce your space cushion.
questions.answerD: Ride in a weaving pattern.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, leave your headlight turned on and ride in a lane position that most easily allows oncoming traffic to see you. Maintain a space cushion that allows you to take evasive action if necessary. Never assume that another driver sees you, even if you make eye contact with the driver.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signals to indicate that you plan to change lanes.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes focused no more than 15 feet in front of your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Not use a headlight during the day.
questions.explanation: To lessen the chances of a crash occurring, you should make yourself visible, communicate your intentions to others, maintain adequate space cushions, search your path of travel at least 12 seconds ahead, identify and separate hazards, and be prepared to react to changing conditions.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Get as close as possible to the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerD: Not signal your intentions, as that may distract the driver you are passing.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. Signal your intentions and check for traffic. Pass when it is safe to do so, then signal and return to your original lane when traffic allows.

questions.question: After drinking, what lessens the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerA: Exercise
questions.answerC: Time
questions.answerD: Food
questions.explanation: The liver burns alcohol at a set rate, and there is nothing you can do to speed along the process. The only way to lessen the effects of alcohol is to give your body the time needed to remove it.

questions.question: When you are being passed by another vehicle, which part of the lane should you ride in?
questions.answerA: The left
questions.answerC: The right
questions.answerD: It doesn’t matter.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest the passing vehicle increases the risk of colliding with them. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous, as it could tempt the driver to re-enter your lane before it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Which of the following is not important when looking for a motorcycle helmet?
questions.answerA: The helmet meets U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: The helmet fits snugly all the way around your head.
questions.answerC: The helmet has no obvious defects, such as cracks or loose padding.
questions.answerD: The helmet looks cool.
questions.explanation: To ensure that a helmet will provide you with as much protection as possible, check to see if it meets U.S. DOT and state standards; fits snugly all the way around your head; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: To lean a motorcycle when making a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Always press on the left handgrip.
questions.answerB: Always press on the right handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press on the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To turn, a motorcycle must lean. To make the motorcycle lean, press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.

questions.question: When riding in a group while passing another vehicle, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Allow one rider to fully pass the other vehicle before another rider begins to pass.
questions.answerB: Allow several members of the group to pass the other vehicle at once.
questions.answerC: Have the last rider in the group wave to the driver being passed to signal that no other motorcycles are approaching.
questions.answerD: Pass in a staggered formation.
questions.explanation: Riders in a group should overtake another vehicle one at a time. Each rider should complete their pass and resume their position in the group formation before the next rider begins to pass.

questions.question: One of the benefits of performing regular maintenance on your motorcycle is that:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle will ride well for a long period of time.
questions.answerB: The maintenance check will take a lot of time.
questions.answerC: Maintenance will be costly.
questions.answerD: Maintenance checks can often prevent parking tickets.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle will continue to ride like new if it is properly maintained and routine inspections become a part of its regular maintenance cycle.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Does not have any markings or tags.
questions.explanation: Any approved helmet will allow a rider to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding. Approved helmets will have labels and markings providing the manufacturer's name, relevant information and instructions, and information about the standards the helmet meets.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: If another driver is following you too closely, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Not worry about them.
questions.answerB: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.answerD: Get off the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Increasing your speed may only encourage the driver to tailgate you at a higher speed.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerA: Should be tucked in.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator:
questions.answerA: Plans to turn left.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: A child passenger:
questions.answerA: Should be placed in front of the operator.
questions.answerB: Should be placed behind the operator.
questions.answerC: Does not have to be able to reach the footrests.
questions.answerD: Should hold onto the motorcycle frame.
questions.explanation: A child passenger on a motorcycle should always ride immediately behind the operator. A child sitting in front may be unable to balance properly and could interfere with the operator's use of the controls.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: Always look through a turn to where you want to go. Turn only your head to look, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good safety tip?
questions.answerA: Slow to a safe speed before turning.
questions.answerB: When turning, lean in the direction you wish to go.
questions.answerC: Avoid dragging your feet on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Avoid looking at other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Slow to a safe speed before beginning a turn and lean in the direction of the turn. Don't drag your feet on the roadway, as you could lose control if they catch on something. Always scan the roadway for other traffic.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: You can see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerD: The sun is out.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: How can you discourage another vehicle from sharing your lane?
questions.answerA: Ride in the middle of your lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of your lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Swerve from side to side in your lane.
questions.explanation: To discourage automobile drivers from trying to share your lane, ride in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: The middle portion of the lane usually contains an oily strip. You should:
questions.answerA: Try to avoid the oily strip when it is raining.
questions.answerB: Ride only on the oily strip, as it provides increased traction.
questions.answerC: Avoid the entire center portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not worry about oil or other items in a lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks build up in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this strip usually still provides enough traction more a motorcycle to operate safely. The strip is generally narrow enough that you can ride to either side of it and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: When riding in a lane of traffic, a motorcycle operator:
questions.answerA: Should always ride in the same part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Should vary their lane position according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Should always ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerD: Should always ride in the left part of the lane.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following should you inspect during a pre-ride check?
questions.answerA: The general wear and tread of your tires
questions.answerB: The amount of cushion your seat has
questions.answerC: The shine of your paint
questions.answerD: The wind direction
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection with a stop sign, riders should:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop sign then proceed through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Ignore the stop sign and move forward to get a better look.
questions.answerC: Stop at the stop sign before moving forward to improve their view of cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Proceed through the intersection without stopping.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection that is controlled by a stop line or stop sign, you must first stop where indicated. You may then edge forward and stop again just short of where the cross traffic lane meets your lane. From that position, lean your body forward and look around buildings, parked cars, or bushes to see if anything is approaching. Make sure your front wheel stays out of the crossroad while you are looking.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerA: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: To best control a motorcycle, a rider should:
questions.answerA: Sit with their arms fully extended.
questions.answerB: Use their arms to hold their body up.
questions.answerC: Keep their knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Keep their feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so that you can use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you hold the handgrips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: A danger of riding next to a row of parked cars is:
questions.answerA: You may not find a parking spot.
questions.answerB: A driver may unexpectedly pull out from the row into your path.
questions.answerC: Others may be driving slowly while looking for a parking spot.
questions.answerD: The road may be uneven.
questions.explanation: Riding next to parked cars presents a number of potential dangers. A driver might pull out of parking space and into your path without looking. Car doors may be opened into your lane and pedestrians may step out from between cars.

questions.question: If you are unable to avoid hitting an object in the roadway, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up before contact.
questions.answerC: Lean the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Stay seated on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid hitting an obstacle in the roadway, you should try to hit it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can before contact, keep your motorcycle upright, rise slightly off of your seat, and roll the throttle slightly to lighten the front end just before impact.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: Use your mirrors when stopped at an intersection:
questions.answerA: To see if vehicles parked on the sides of the street are entering traffic.
questions.answerB: To look for vehicles changing lanes.
questions.answerC: To watch for vehicles behind you that may not be slowing down.
questions.answerD: To see if someone is planning to turn behind you.
questions.explanation: When you are stopped at an intersection, use your mirrors to check for cars approaching you from behind. The drivers may not notice you until they are too close and you may need to react.

questions.question: Motorcycle riders should choose footwear with soles that:
questions.answerA: Are made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.
questions.answerC: Have tall heels.
questions.answerD: Are made of soft, flimsy material.
questions.explanation: Choose riding boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Choose footwear with soles made of hard, durable, slip-resistant material.

questions.question: If you are riding in the right side of your lane while following a car:
questions.answerA: You are likely riding in the best position to be seen.
questions.answerB: You may not be seen unless the driver uses their side mirror.
questions.answerC: The driver will most likely assume you are there.
questions.answerD: You are discouraging other drivers from sharing your lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a passenger vehicle, it is usually best to ride in the center of the lane so you will be visible in the driver's rearview mirror. Most drivers check their rearview mirrors much more often than their side mirrors, so this lane position will increase your chances of being seen.

questions.question: When making a turn:
questions.answerA: There is less traction available for stopping.
questions.answerB: There is more traction available for stopping.
questions.answerC: Stopping is no different than making a stop on a straightaway.
questions.answerD: Stopping should never be attempted.
questions.explanation: It is possible to brake while turning, but it should be done with great care. When a motorcycle is leaning to turn, there is less traction available for stopping because some of the traction is being used for turning.

questions.question: You should do a pre-ride inspection:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: A small technical fault can have much more serious consequences on a motorcycle than on a car. To avoid these consequences, inspect your motorcycle before every ride.

questions.question: As a motorcycle operator, you can help others see you by:
questions.answerA: Riding with your headlight off.
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles closely.
questions.answerD: Not using turn signals.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen, wear brightly-colored clothing, use your headlight at all times, and use your turn signals.

questions.question: Successful motorcyclists know they are safest when they are:
questions.answerA: Seen by other motorists.
questions.answerC: On the side of the road.
questions.answerD: In the left side of the lane.
questions.explanation: Successful motorcyclists know that they are safest when they are clearly seen by other road users. Use your headlight, brake light, signals, and lane position to maximize your visibility.

questions.question: The human body rids itself of about one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumes seven drinks in three hours, how many drinks likely remain in that person’s system three hours after their final drink?
questions.answerA: Two
questions.answerC: Four
questions.answerD: Five
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks remaining in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since their last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. For example: a person who has consumed seven drinks in three hours would have a minimum of four drinks remaining in their system three hours later.

questions.question: What should a motorcyclist do to prevent possible injury when riding on a slippery surface?
questions.answerA: Increase their speed.
questions.answerC: Make sudden moves.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When riding on a slippery surface, it is safest to decrease your speed. Making sudden moves on a slippery surface could cause your motorcycle to skid. Do not travel on the shoulder to escape a slippery road.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head to check for vehicles in your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Rely on your mirrors to show you all of your surroundings.
questions.answerC: Point in the direction of the lane change.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get ahead of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. You should always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes. Do not rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerA: Heightened riding abilities.
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: Hearing protection is:
questions.answerA: Not needed if you wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Needed in addition to a helmet.
questions.answerC: Only needed on windy days.
questions.answerD: Not needed if you are carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Exposure to engine and wind noise can damage your hearing, even if you are wearing a helmet. Hearing protection can guard against this while still allowing you to hear essential sounds like horns and sirens.

questions.question: When entering a highway or curve, motorcyclists riding in a group should:
questions.answerA: Ride single-file.
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: While a staggered group formation is usually best, it is better to switch to a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: Riding alongside a car:
questions.answerA: Is encouraged.
questions.answerB: Can place you in a blind spot.
questions.answerC: Is not an issue unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Can make driving easier for the other motorist.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous because it may place you in the driver's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle will block your path of escape.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake suddenly.
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: When braking, you should use:
questions.answerA: The front brake only.
questions.answerC: Both front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Either the front or rear brake, but not both.
questions.explanation: You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Kick it away.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If a dog is chasing your motorcycle, downshift and slowly approach the dog. Once you have gotten close to the animal, accelerate and leave it behind. Do not attempt to kick it.

questions.question: The control for the rear brake is usually located:
questions.answerA: On the right handlebar.
questions.answerC: Near the left foot.
questions.answerD: Near the right foot.
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually operated with the right foot.

questions.question: When preparing to pass a vehicle on the left, it is important to ride on the left side of your lane because:
questions.answerA: The right side could be slippery.
questions.answerB: It will give you the best chance of spotting hazards in the next lane.
questions.answerC: People don’t usually expect to be passed on their left.
questions.answerD: It will place you in the rearview mirror of the car in front of you.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will increase your line of sight and make your more visible to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerA: The pavement is slippery.
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerA: Two
questions.answerC: Four
questions.answerD: Five
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: The only way to rid your body of alcohol is through:
questions.answerA: Time.
questions.answerC: Exercising.
questions.answerD: Taking a cold shower.
questions.explanation: The only way to remove the alcoholic content of a drink from your body is to allow your body time to eliminate it. There are no shortcuts to sobering up.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: Normally, you should maintain a following distance of:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should allow at least two seconds of distance between you and the vehicle ahead of you. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than ideal.

questions.question: For routine braking:
questions.answerA: You should only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: You should only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: You should alternate between the front and rear brakes to maximize the life of the brakes.
questions.answerD: You should always use both the front and rear brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes every time that you slow or stop.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: It is a good idea to drag your feet.
questions.answerB: Your toes should be pointed downward.
questions.answerC: You should keep your feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.answerD: You should try to keep your feet away from the controls.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper balance, your feet should be placed firmly on the footrests and not dragged on the ground. Do not point your toes downward, as this may cause them to catch on the road. Keep your feet near the controls so you can reach them quickly, if needed.

questions.question: When looking for a protective jacket or pair of pants, you should look for:
questions.answerA: Items made of leather.
questions.answerC: Items made of light materials.
questions.answerD: Items that are darkly-colored.
questions.explanation: It is safest to wear long pants and a jacket to fully cover your arms and legs while riding. Clothing made of leather can provide the highest level of protection.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks need to be consumed before a rider may begin to feel the effects?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerC: Six
questions.answerD: More than eight
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can affect a person's ability to ride. It is both illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: If a driver is following you too closely, you should:
questions.answerA: Flash your brake light before you slow to warn the other driver.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Slow down.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, it is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing down. A tailgater may be concentrating on you and not see upcoming hazards that require traffic to slow down.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: When packing a load on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: The heavier items should go toward the front.
questions.answerB: The heavier items should go toward the rear.
questions.answerC: Mounting loads behind the rear axle is recommended.
questions.answerD: Lighter items should be stored in front of you.
questions.explanation: Loads should be positioned forward with heavier items toward the front of the load. Loads should be over or in front of the rear axle. Lighter items should be packed behind you.

questions.question: How can a motorcycle operator discourage lane sharing by other drivers?
questions.answerA: By giving dirty looks to other drivers
questions.answerB: By riding in the center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: By riding in the left portion of the lane
questions.answerD: By riding in a zigzag pattern
questions.explanation: By riding in the center portion of your lane, you will ensure that there is not a large space on either side of your motorcycle. Minimizing those spaces can help deter drivers from trying to share the lane with you.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerA: Jump off the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield must:
questions.answerA: Fasten securely.
questions.answerC: Not allow for eyeglasses to fit underneath.
questions.answerD: Restrict your vision to the sides.
questions.explanation: To be effective, an eye or face shield must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; allow clear views to both sides; fasten securely; permit air to pass through to prevent fogging; and allow room for eyeglasses or sunglasses, if needed.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride slower than the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and the brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Pull in the clutch when turning.
questions.explanation: To help reduce your reaction time, you should cover the clutch and brakes. This is especially helpful when riding through areas where potential hazards are likely.

questions.question: Maximum front-line braking is accomplished by:
questions.answerA: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerC: Using both brakes.
questions.answerD: Using the rear brake while downshifting.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by fully applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel. You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride within a foot of the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Signal only when you feel like it.
questions.answerD: Stay alert and be prepared to act to avoid a crash.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: Experienced riders use the acronym "SIPDE" as a way to remain aware of conditions around them. What does the "E" stand for in "SIPDE?"
questions.answerA: Explain
questions.answerC: Execute
questions.answerD: Early
questions.explanation: SIPDE is a five-step process that experienced riders use to make judgements and take action while traveling. The letters in SIPDE stand for Scan, Identify, Predict, Decide, and Execute.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: It is a good idea to wear reflective clothing:
questions.answerA: At night.
questions.answerC: At dusk.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Wearing reflective and brightly-colored clothing is always a good idea when riding a motorcycle. Crashes occur in broad daylight and at night, so it is best to wear highly visible clothing at any time of day.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Do one, then the other.
questions.answerB: Do both at the same time.
questions.answerC: Always apply the brakes first, then swerve.
questions.answerD: Try instead to use only the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should perform both actions separately. Brake then swerve, or swerve then brake. Do not do both at the same time.

questions.question: To carry a passenger, you must have:
questions.answerA: An extra set of foot pegs for the passenger.
questions.answerB: A seat that accommodates two people.
questions.answerC: Proper gear for both yourself and the passenger.
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: To carry a passenger safely, you must have a seat that will properly accommodate both you and the passenger without crowding and a set of foot pegs for the passenger. Motorcycle passengers should wear the same types of protective gear that operators wear.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in:
questions.answerA: The left side of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Either the right or center portions of the lane.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass another vehicle on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane. This lane position will provide you with the most effective view of the passing lane.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly than you would normally.
questions.answerB: Start slowing earlier than you would normally.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.answerD: Not communicate with the passenger while riding.
questions.explanation: Because of a passenger's additional weight, a motorcycle will respond more slowly with a passenger on board than with just one occupant. With a passenger, you should travel a bit more slowly than you normally would, start slowing sooner than you normally would, and increase your following distance. Always warn your passenger of any special conditions ahead.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane:
questions.answerA: Is always the best part of the lane for a motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Often contains oil and grease, but is usually safe for riding.
questions.answerC: Often contains oil and grease, and is never safe for riding.
questions.answerD: Is the smoothest part of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of each lane. Unless the road is wet, this area still generally offers enough traction for motorcyclists to safely ride. You should still avoid riding on big buildups of oil and grease, often found at busy intersections or near toll booths.

questions.question: Face shields and goggles:
questions.answerA: Will likely never need to be replaced.
questions.answerB: Will develop scratches and become brittle, requiring regular replacement.
questions.answerC: Should be made of breakable materials so they can break away in the event of a crash.
questions.answerD: Should not allow air to pass through.
questions.explanation: Face shields and goggles, being made of plastic, will develop scratches and become brittle as they age. Replace them regularly to ensure maximum protection and comfort.

questions.question: Usually, a minimum following distance of _____ should be maintained.
questions.answerA: One second
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.answerD: Four seconds
questions.explanation: Generally, you should maintain a minimum following distance of two seconds. Increase your following distance to at least three seconds whenever you are riding under conditions that are less than ideal.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerA: Insects.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: Unlike most food and drinks, alcohol does not need to be digested. This means that:
questions.answerA: Within minutes of being consumed, the alcohol reaches the brain and begins to affect the drinker.
questions.answerB: The alcohol never gets removed from the body.
questions.answerC: It takes a long time to feel the effects of alcohol.
questions.answerD: Once it is in your system, your body gets rid of the alcohol quickly.
questions.explanation: Because it does not have to be digested, alcohol enters a person's bloodstream quickly and reaches the brain within minutes. It gets eliminated from the body at a relatively slow rate: about one drink per hour.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerA: Too dangerous to be used by inexperienced operators.
questions.answerC: Meant to occasionally assist the rear brake.
questions.answerD: To be used with the rear brake.
questions.explanation: Use both the front and rear brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: As weight transfers to the front of your bike while you are braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Gradually increase pressure to the front brake.
questions.answerC: Not worry. The weight transfer will not have an effect on your motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Try to lock the front tire.
questions.explanation: While you are braking, gradually increase the amount of pressure applied to the front brake lever as the weight of the bike is transferred forward to the front tire.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before.
questions.answerB: Not assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before and explain the process.
questions.answerC: Not let them ask questions.
questions.answerD: Not bother with explaining anything since they are only a passenger and not in control of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle passenger needs to understand how to ensure a safe ride ride for both themselves and the operator. An operator should never assume the passenger already knows what to do. Give a passenger complete instructions before every ride.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: When securing a load, you should place the load:
questions.answerA: As high as possible.
questions.answerC: On a sissy bar.
questions.answerD: Only on one side of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Secured loads should be low. Putting them too high up, such as on a sissy bar, can raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and upset its balance. Loads should be as evenly distributed as possible on each side of the motorcycle to avoid pulling the bike to one side.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the:
questions.answerA: Motorcycle could lurch and the rear tire could skid.
questions.answerC: Front tire will likely skid.
questions.answerD: Engine will make a loud noise.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, the motorcycle will lurch and the rear wheel may skid.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerA: Be free of scratches.
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: To help provide space for drivers attempting to merge into your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerB: Merge into the next lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about it, since they are the ones trying to merge.
questions.answerD: Ride on the far left shoulder.
questions.explanation: Drivers merging onto a highway and into your lane may not notice your motorcycle. Give them plenty of space to safely merge by moving into a different lane, if you can.

questions.question: Can clothing help prevent injuries in the event of a crash?
questions.answerA: No, clothing is not really for protection.
questions.answerB: No, clothing is more of a personal choice.
questions.answerC: Yes, but only if garments are very loose and flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Yes, if pants and a jacket cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.explanation: Appropriate clothing can reduce the risk of injury in a crash. Choose a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs, are made of sturdy material, and are snug enough that they do not flap in the wind.

questions.question: A group of riders should pass another vehicle:
questions.answerA: In a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: One at a time.
questions.answerD: In a splintered formation.
questions.explanation: On a two-lane highway, a group of riders should pass another vehicle one at a time. The second rider should not begin to pass until the first rider has safely re-entered the original lane. Riders should continue in this pattern until they have all safely passed the vehicle.

questions.question: When turning left, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the right handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press both handgrips at the same time.
questions.answerD: Not press either handgrip.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle must lean to make a turn. To make it lean in the appropriate direction, press the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: Where is the gearshift lever located?
questions.answerA: In front of the left footrest
questions.answerB: In front of the right footrest
questions.answerC: On the left handgrip
questions.answerD: On the right handgrip
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever is located in front of the left footrest and is operated with the left foot.

questions.question: To carry a passenger, you may need to adjust all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tire pressure.
questions.answerC: Headlight position.
questions.answerD: Brake light position.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle carrying a passenger will sit differently than usual due to the additional weight. You may need to adjust the tire pressure, suspension, shocks, headlight, and mirrors to compensate for the shift.

questions.question: If a tire goes flat while you are riding and you must stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both brakes and stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Shift your weight toward the good tire.
questions.answerC: Brake on the good tire and steer to the side of the road.
questions.answerD: Relax on the handgrips.
questions.explanation: If either of your tires go flat while you are riding, hold the handgrips firmly, ease off the throttle, and maintain a straight course. If you need to brake, gradually apply the brake to the tire that is not flat. As you slow down, edge to the side of the road, squeeze the clutch, and stop.

questions.question: When you are being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in any portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind, stay in the center portion of your lane. This will discourage the other driver from re-entering your lane before it is safe.

questions.question: When planning a long group ride, which of the following ideas should not be implemented?
questions.answerA: The lengths of travel segments should be based on the least experienced rider.
questions.answerB: Breaks should be minimized so the riders can get to their destination as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leaders.
questions.answerD: The group should maintain a staggered riding formation.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, the length of a route and the lengths of segments of travel should be based on the skill level of the least experienced rider. Groups of riders should take regular breaks to reduce fatigue. Inexperienced riders should be placed behind the leader so more experienced riders can keep an eye on them from behind. It is generally best to ride in a staggered formation.

questions.question: If you are being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Kick it away.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles often seem to attract dogs. If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: When making normal stops, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: Make it a habit to always use both brakes when slowing or stopping, even for normal, non-emergency stops.

questions.question: When it starts to rain, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.explanation: The center of a lane can be especially hazardous when wet. When it begins to rain, avoid the center of the road by riding in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track is often the best option.

questions.question: If your motorcycle starts to wobble, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Downshift.
questions.answerC: Grip the handlebars firmly and close the throttle gradually.
questions.answerD: Gradually apply your brakes.
questions.explanation: Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble because doing so will only make the motorcycle more unstable. Instead, grip the handlebars firmly, slow down by gradually closing the throttle, move your weight as far forward and downward as possible, and pull off the road as soon as you can. Avoid applying the brakes, as this may also worsen the wobble.

questions.question: When riding downhill on a motorcycle with a sidecar:
questions.answerA: Stopping will be easier than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerB: Stopping will take longer than when riding without a sidecar.
questions.answerC: You cannot stop.
questions.answerD: Stopping is about as easy as it is when riding without the sidecar.
questions.explanation: Riding with a sidecar increases the weight of a motorcycle and increases the braking force needed to stop the motorcycle. Slowing and stopping take longer when riding a vehicle downhill than when riding on a flat surface.

questions.question: Head and neck injuries can be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Wearing a helmet.
questions.answerC: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerD: Wearing goggles.
questions.explanation: The risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by wearing a high-quality helmet. A helmet is a rider's best defense against injury in the case of an accident.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep going and hope to wake up.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Get off the road and rest.
questions.explanation: You should avoid riding if you are tired. When making a long trip, take rest breaks at least every two hours to reduce the risk of becoming fatigued.
